CHANGE.ITEM: Corrected 0 illegibles of 0. Converted 0 illegibles to GAP DESC="illegible".

DIV1.P: DUKE upon DUKE, An Excellent New PLAY-HOUSE BALLAD.
Set to Musick by Mr. HOLDECOMBE.
LONDON: Printed for A. MOOR near St. Paul's Church, and Sold by the Booksellers. 1723. (Price Three Pence.)

DIV1.HEAD: DUKE upon DUKE, &c.
DIV1.P: TO Lordings Proud I tune my SONG Who feast in Bow'r or Hall; Tho' Dukes they be, Yet Dukes shall see, that Pride will have a Fall, that Pride will have a Fall.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: TO Lordings Proud I tune my Song,
Who Feast in Bow'r or Hall;
Tho' Dukes they be, yet Dukes shall see

L.HI: That Pride will have a fall.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Now that this same it is Right Sooth,
Full plainly doth appear;
From what befel JOHN DUKE OF GUISE,
And NIC of LANCASTERE.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: When Richard Coeur de Lyon Reign'd,
(which means a Lyon's Heart)
Like him his Barons rag'd and roar'd,
Each play'd a Lyon's Part.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: A Word and Blow was then enough,
Such Honour did them Prick,
If you but turn'd your Cheek, a Cuff,
And if your Ae, a Kick.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Look in their Face, they tweak'd your Nose,
At every turn fell to't;
Come near, they trode upon your Toes;
They fought from Head to Foot.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: Of these the Duke of Lancastere
Stood Paramount in Pride;
He kick'd and cuff'd, and tweak'd and trode
His Foes and Friends beside.

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: Firm on his Front his Beaver sate,
So broad it hid his Chin;
For why, he thought no Man his Mate,
And fear'd to Tan his Skin.

LG.HEAD: VIII.
LG.L: With Spanish Wool he dy'd his Cheek,
With Essence oyl'd his Hair;
No vixen Civet Cat more Sweet,
Nor more could Scratch and Tear.

LG.HEAD: IX.
LG.L: Right Tall he made himself to show,
Tho' made full short by Gd;
And when all other Dukes did Bow,
This Duke did only Nod.

LG.HEAD: X.
LG.L: Yet Courteous, Blith and Debonaire,
To GUISE's DUKE was he;
Never was such a Loving Pair,
Why did they disagree?

LG.HEAD: XI.
LG.L: Oh! thus it was, he lov'd him dear,
And cast how to requite him;
And having no Friend left but This,
He deem'd it meet to fight him.

LG.HEAD: XII.
LG.L: Forthwith he drench'd his desperate Quill,
And thus he did Indite,
This Eve at Wisk OUR SELF will Play,
Sir Duke, Be here to Night.

LG.HEAD: XIII.
LG.L: Ah no! ah no! the Guileless GUISE,
Demurely did reply;

L.HI: I cannot Go, nor yet can Stand,
So sore the Gout have I.

LG.HEAD: XIV.
LG.L: The DUKE in Wrath call'd for his Steeds,
And fiercely drove them on;
Lord! Lord! how rattled then thy Stones,
O Kingly Kensington!

LG.HEAD: XV.
LG.L: All in a Trice on GUISE he rush'd,
Thrust out his Lady Dear;
He tweak'd his Nose, trod on his Toes,
And smote him on the Ear.

LG.HEAD: XVI.
LG.L: But mark! how midst of Victory
Fate shews an Old Dog-Trick;
Up leap'd DUKE JOHN and knock'd him down,
And so down fell DUKE NIC.

LG.HEAD: XVII.
LG.L: Alass, Oh NIC! Oh NIC, alass!
Right did thy Gossip call thee,
As who should say, Alass the Day
When JOHN of GUISE shall maul thee.

LG.HEAD: XVIII.
LG.L: For on thee did he clap his Chair,
And on that Chair did sit?
And look'd as if he meant therein
To do what was not fit.

LG.HEAD: XIX.
LG.L: Up didst thou look, Oh woful DUKE,
Thy Mouth yet durst not ope,
Certes, for Fear of finding there
A Td instead of Trope.

LG.HEAD: XX.
LG.L: " Lye there thou Caitiff vile, quoth GUISE,
" No Sheet is here to save thee,
" The Casememt it is shut likewise,
" Beneath my Feet I have thee.

LG.HEAD: XXI.
LG.L: " If thou hast ought to say, now speak,
Then Lancaster did cry,
" Knowest thou not ME, not yet thy self,
" Who Thou, and WHO AM I?

LG.HEAD: XXII.
LG.L: " Know'st Thou not ME, who God be prais'd,
" have bawl'd and quarell'd more
" Than all the Line of Lancaster
" That battled heretofore?

LG.HEAD: XXIII.
LG.L: " In Senates fam'd for many a Speech,
" And what some Awe must give Ye,
" Tho' laid thus low beneath thy Breech,
" Still of the Council Privy.

LG.HEAD: XXIV.
LG.L: " Still of the Dutchy Chancellor,
" Durante Life I have it,
" And turn (as now thou dost on me)
" My Ae on those that gave it.

LG.HEAD: XXV.
LG.L: But now the Servants they rush'd in,
And DUKE NIC up leap'd He,

L.HI: I will not cope against such Odds,

LG.L: But GUISE, I'll fight with Thee.

LG.HEAD: XXVI.

L.HI: To Morrow with Thee will I fight

LG.L: No, not to Morrow, but to Night,
Quoth GUISE, I'll fight with Thee.

LG.HEAD: XXVII.
LG.L: And now the Sun declining low,
Bestreak'd with Blood the Skies,
When with his Sword at Saddle Bow
Rode forth the Valiant GUISE.

LG.HEAD: XXVIII.
LG.L: Full gently praunc'd he on the Lawn,
Oft rowl'd his Eye around,
And from his Sirrup stretch'd to find

L.HI: Who was not to be found.

LG.HEAD: XXIX.
LG.L: Long brandish'd he his Blade in Air,
Long look'd the Field all o're,
At length he spy'd the merry Men brown,
And eke the Coach and Four.

LG.HEAD: XXX.
LG.L: From out the Boot bold NICHOLAS
Did wave his Hand so white,
As pointing out the gloomy Glade
Whereat he meant to fight.

LG.HEAD: XXXI.
LG.L: All in that dreadful Hour so calm
Was Lancaster to see,
As if he meant to take the Air,
Or only take a Fee.

LG.HEAD: XXXII.
LG.L: And so he did, for to New Court
His trowling Wheels they run;
Not that he shunn'd the doubtful Strife,

LG.HEAD: XXXIII.
LG.L: Back in the dark, by Brompton Park,
He turn'd up thro' the Gore,
So slunk to Campden House so high,
All in his Coach and four.

LG.HEAD: XXXIV.
LG.L: Mean while the GUISE did fret and fume,
A Sight it was to see,
Benumm'd beneath the Evening Dew,
Under the Greenwood Tree.

LG.HEAD: XXXV.
LG.L: Then wet and weary home he far'd,
Sore mutt'ring all the Way,
The Day I meet NIC he shall rue
The Cudgel of that Day.

LG.HEAD: XXXVI.
LG.L: Mean time on every pissing Post
Paste me this Recreant's Name,
So that each Pisser-by shall read,
And piss against the same.

LG.HEAD: XXXVII.
LG.L: Now God preserve our GRACIOUS KING,
And grant his Nobles all
May learn this Lesson from Duke Nic,
That Pride will have a Fall.
